creator: banyek@gmail.com
text:
So, I've got 2 apache servers, named "A" and "B"

Server A is reachable from the cloud, Server B is only reachable from the intranet. 
I have to access some documents from Server B from the cloud, so I made an apache proxy on server "B" to reach server A like this

ProxyPass /some_page http://ServerB.intra/some_page
ProxyPassReverse /some_page http://ServerB.intra/some_page

The Server A's documentroot is protected via .htpasswd and allowed only an user "UserA"

The Server B's /some_page is protected via .htpasswd and allowed only an user "UserB"

When I navigated to http://ServerA/some_page then I got an authentication window, from ServerA's realm and I authenticated as "UserA" then I got an another authentication window (From ServerB's realm of course) and I authenticated as UserB ... and THEN I got ServerA's authentication again ... and then ServerB of course, and so on...

OK, I made a dirty hack, so I can auth on ServerB as UserA now, and it's working now, but it looks like a bug for me, so I share it with you guys.

Best regards,
  Balazs Pocze

> Please use a user support forum for setup questions.
> 
> In this instance, you seem to be looking for proxy-chain-auth.

No, I didn't wanted to use proxy-chain-auth, I just tried to use 2 different authentication creditentals at two different servers. For the record I've read this : http://httpd.apache.org/docs/2.2/mod/mod_proxy_http.html#env
about proxy-chain-auth and here's described, if I wanted to send my creditentals to the next proxy, then I have to use this... but that is what I didn't want to do. 
Literally I wanted do 2 different auth at two hosts. 
(BTW this is really looks invalid, because it can be a http protocol restriction about basic auth)
